Specify a P-spline model for an age effect

Spline.Rd

Specify a P-spline (penalised spline) model for an age effect. A P-spline is flexible, but favours profiles that are relatively smooth.

Usage

Spline(df = NULL, scale = 1)

Arguments

df

Degrees of freedom for spline. The default is 0.7 times the number of age groups, or 4, whichever is higher.

scale

Scale for error term. The default is 1.

Value

An object of class "BayesRates_spec_spline".

Mathematical details

The model for the age effect, on the log scale, is

$$\beta = X \gamma$$

where

  • \(\beta\) is a vector of age effects,

  • \(X\) is a matrix holding the basis functions for the spline, with df columns, and

  • \(\gamma\) is a vector of coefficients, with df elements.

The elements of \(\gamma\) are assumed to follow a second order random walk,

$$(\gamma_a - \gamma_{a-1}) - (\gamma_{a-1} - \gamma_{a-2}) \sim \text{N}(0, \sigma^2)$$

Parameter \(\sigma\) has prior

$$\sigma \sim \text{N}^+(0, a^2)$$

where \(\text{N}^+\) denotes a half-normal distribution, and a value for \(a\) is supplied by the user.

See also

  • RW2() is an alternative approach to modelling age effects, based on a random walk.

  • TimeFixed() specifies time trends where the age pattern is fixed over time.

  • TimeVarying() specifies time trends where the age pattern varies over time

Spline() uses function splines::bs() internally.

Examples

Spline()
#> < Object of class "BayesRates_spec_spline" >
#>           scale: 1
Spline(df = 10)
#> < Object of class "BayesRates_spec_spline" >
#>              df: 10
#>           scale: 1
